items.title: Spotlight on SIG Architecture: API Governance
items.summary:
<p><em>This is the fifth interview of a SIG Architecture Spotlight series that covers the different
subprojects, and we will be covering <a href="https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/sig-architecture/README.md#architecture-and-api-governance-1">SIG Architecture: API
Governanc
items.reason: Kubernetes API governance is a core architectural topic not yet covered in the wiki; creating a dedicated article will help users understand SIG Architecture and governance practices.

items.title: How Medplum Secured Their Healthcare Platform with Docker Hardened Images (DHI)
items.summary: Special thanks to Cody Ebberson and the Medplum team for their open-source contribution and for sharing their migration experience with the community. A real-world example of migrating a HIPAA-compliant EHR platform to DHI with minimal code changes. Healthcare software runs on trust. When patient da
items.reason: Shows a real‑world use of Docker Hardened Images for HIPAA‑compliant healthcare; valuable security and compliance content missing from the wiki.

items.title: The Multi-Model Database for AI Agents: Deploy SurrealDB with Docker Extension
items.summary: When it comes to building dynamic and real-work solutions, developers need to stitch multiple databases (relational, document, graph, vector, time-series, search) together and build complex API layers to integrate them. This generates significant complexity, cost, and operational risk, and reduces s
items.reason: Introduces multi‑model databases for AI agents and Docker extensions – a niche but growing area that warrants its own documentation.

items.title: Running NanoClaw in a Docker Shell Sandbox
items.summary: Ever wanted to run a personal AI assistant that monitors your WhatsApp messages 24/7, but worried about giving it access to your entire system? Docker Sandboxes' new shell sandbox type is the perfect solution. In this post, I'll show you how to run NanoClaw, a lightweight Claude-powered WhatsApp ass
items.reason: Demonstrates Docker Shell Sandbox for running AI assistants; relevant for security‑focused container usage guides.

items.title: How to solve the context size issues with context packing with Docker Model Runner and Agentic Compose
items.summary: If you’ve worked with local language models, you’ve probably run into the context window limit, especially when using smaller models on less powerful machines. While it’s an unavoidable constraint, techniques like context packing make it surprisingly manageable. Hello, I’m Philippe, and I am a Princ
items.reason: Context‑packing techniques for local LLMs are increasingly important for developers; the wiki lacks coverage of these optimization strategies.

items.title: Hardened Images Are Free. Now What?
items.summary: Docker Hardened Images are now free, covering Alpine, Debian, and over 1,000 images including databases, runtimes, and message buses. For security teams, this changes the economics of container vulnerability management. DHI includes security fixes from Docker’s security team, which simplifies securi
items.reason: Docker Hardened Images becoming free impacts container security economics; a dedicated article will help security teams evaluate the change.

items.title: How AI is reshaping developer choice (and Octoverse data proves it)
items.summary:
AI is rewiring developer preferences through convenience loops. Octoverse 2025 reveals how AI compatibility is becoming the new standard for technology choice.
The post How AI is reshaping developer choice (and Octoverse data proves it) appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: AI’s influence on developer tool choice is a strategic trend; the wiki should document how AI integration shapes ecosystem decisions.

items.title: What to expect for open source in 2026
items.summary:
Let’s dig into the 2025’s open source data on GitHub to see what we can learn about the future.
The post What to expect for open source in 2026 appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: Forecasts for open‑source in 2026 based on GitHub data provide forward‑looking insight that is currently absent from the wiki.

items.title: Securing the AI software supply chain: Security results across 67 open source projects
items.summary:
Learn how The GitHub Secure Open Source Fund helped 67 critical AI‑stack projects accelerate fixes, strengthen ecosystems, and advance open source resilience.
The post Securing the AI software supply chain: Security results across 67 open source projects appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: Security of the AI software supply chain is a critical emerging topic; documenting the GitHub Secure Open Source Fund findings adds valuable security context.

items.title: Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows
items.summary:
Discover GitHub Agentic Workflows, now in technical preview. Build automations using coding agents in GitHub Actions to handle triage, documentation, code quality, and more.
The post Automate repository tasks with GitHub Agentic Workflows   appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
items.reason: GitHub Agentic Workflows introduce AI‑driven automation in CI/CD; the wiki needs a guide on setup, use‑cases, and limitations.

items.title: Welcome to the Eternal September of open source. Here’s what we plan to do for maintainers.
items.summary:
Open source is hitting an “Eternal September.” As contribution friction drops, maintainers are adapting with new trust signals, triage approaches, and community-led solutions.
The post Welcome to the Eternal September of open source. Here’s what we plan to do for maintainers. appeared first on
items.reason: The “Eternal September” concept highlights evolving maintainer challenges; a wiki page would help maintainers navigate new trust signals and triage methods.

items.title: oven-sh/bun bun-v1.3.9
items.summary:
To install Bun v1.3.9
```bash
curl -fsSL https://bun.sh/install | bash
# or you can use npm
# npm install -g bun
```

Windows:
```bash
powershell -c "irm bun.sh/install.ps1|iex"
```

To upgrade to Bun v1.3.9:
```bash
bun upgrade
```

### [Read Bun v1.3.9's release notes on Bun's blo
items.reason: Bun v1.3.9 release introduces runtime changes; a wiki entry will help JavaScript developers evaluate upgrade impact.
